red_flag_response:
8/10

Why this is strong
- You’re prioritizing sobriety over people who undermine it. That’s exactly what recovery-boundaries look like.
- Clear timing anchors (lease end, job opportunity) reduce chaos.
- You have savings and a defined plan (NC email, number change).
- Their behavior (minimizing addiction, pushing alcohol, body-shaming) is genuinely harmful; leaving that environment is protective.
- You’ve already been building insight and support (counselor, sponsor, community).

Why it’s not a 10 (yet)
- Stacking two major stressors at once (no-contact + interstate move) raises relapse risk if support isn’t airtight.
- Your sponsor just moved—your support net may be thinner during a big transition.
- $12k is workable for Denver but tight if moving costs and deposits run high.
- Make sure the “amazing job” is a signed offer with start date/benefits before you burn ships.

Tighten the plan to make it a 9–10
- Get a written offer in hand; confirm start date, benefits, and probation period.
- Line up housing before arrival and budget move-in costs + 3 months of expenses in cash.
- Lock in local recovery now: identify meetings in Denver, line up a temporary/new sponsor, put 2–3 meetings on your first week’s calendar.
- Book a therapist in Denver (or telehealth) before the move; first appointment within 2 weeks of arrival.
- Create a relapse-prevention checklist for the move week (HALT checks, daily call/text to a sober buddy, sleep/food plan).
- Keep one non-intrusive contact channel (PO box or a filtered email) so you don’t feel trapped; you can still block phones/socials.
- Do basic safety/digital hygiene: change passwords, update 2FA to new number, forward mail, update HR/payroll contacts.

On second-guessing
- Expect it to spike in the first 2–6 weeks and ease by around 60–90 days if you stick to no-contact.
- Write a one-page “why I’m doing this” note; read it when the nostalgia hits.
- Try a 90-day no-contact commitment; reassess with your sponsor/therapist after that window.

Bottom line: This is a bold, self-protective move that aligns with your recovery. Lock down the job/housing/support pieces and you’ll turn a very good decision into a great one. And congrats on 18 months—you’re doing the hard, healthy thing.
reasonable_response:
9/10.

Why so high: You’re making a big change for clear recovery reasons, not impulse. You’ve got 18 months sober, a therapist, a sponsor, a transition plan, savings plus relocation support, a realistic communication script for family, and you’ve already plugged into a Denver recovery network. The timing with your lease and the family’s gradual progress all point to a thoughtful, well-sequenced move.

What keeps it from a 10: Any relocation can spike stress and isolation, which are classic relapse risks. The only gaps I see are making sure care is truly continuous during the move and that the first 30–60 days in Denver are structured and crowded with recovery support.

Suggestions to lock it in:
- Pre-schedule your first month: at least 5 meetings your first week, 3–5/week for 60–90 days. Meet your new sponsor in person within 72 hours of arrival.
- Keep therapy continuous via telehealth until you’re established locally; book your first Denver session before you move.
- Put a written relapse-prevention plan on your phone: triggers, coping steps, meeting list, three people you call in order, and a same-day “if I wobble” plan.
- Choose housing with proximity to meetings and sober activities; avoid high-drinking nightlife zones if they’re a trigger.
- Structure contact with family: set call windows, topics you’ll avoid, and a firm end-the-call script (“I love you; I’m ending this now and we can try again tomorrow.”).
- Front-load connection to reduce isolation: service at meetings, a weekly coffee/walk with recovery peers, and a standing Sunday check-in with your current sponsor for the first month.
- Plan for an emotional dip after the move; normalize it and pre-commit to asking for help fast, not perfectly handling it alone.

Overall, this is a strong, well-prepared decision aligned with your recovery. You’re ready—and you’re doing it the right way.

red_flag_response:
Score: 2/10

Your relationship might be great, but the way you’re about to do this is high-risk. You’re combining a fast timeline, pressure, and early financial entanglement with someone you’ve known for four months.

Big red flags:
- Crisis-driven move-in. You’re solving his housing emergency, not making a calm, joint plan.
- You’d be wiring $3,600—about 40% of your savings—after already lending him money. “Invoice clears next week” and “big contracts in January” are just promises.
- If he misses even one payment, you’re on the hook for $2,400/month plus utilities; your cushion evaporates fast.
- 48-hour notice, borrowed money, and urgency to wire funds are a pattern of instability and pressure, not reliability.
- “When you know, you know” is romantic; it’s not a financial plan.

If you still want to move toward living together, change the structure:
- Do not wire or sign anything unless he puts up his full half of the deposit and first month directly to the landlord upfront.
- Both names on the lease, separate finances, and a written cost-sharing and exit plan (who keeps what, how to unwind).
- Proof of income and reserves from both of you; each with at least 3 months’ rent saved. He should pay his share directly to the landlord via autopay.
- If he’s in a bind now, let him stay short-term while he secures his own lease or a sublet, then revisit moving in after a couple more months together.

Decor tip for when it’s truly shared: agree a budget, create a joint mood board, give each other veto rights, and record who owns big-ticket items before buying.

Missing this apartment is cheaper than getting stuck in a lopsided commitment. Protect your savings and slow the financial part down.
reasonable_response:
Rating: 9/10.

Why so high: You’ve hit nearly all the smart boxes—timeline (14 months, lots of overnights), a one-month trial run, a 2BR for space, financial transparency, separate emergency funds, written house rules, and the move will improve your savings rate. That’s a very balanced, low-drama way to cohabit.

To make it a 10/10, lock these in before signing:
- Exit plan: If you split, who keeps the apartment, how the deposit/furniture are divided, and a 30-day move-out timeline. Put it in writing.
- Lease and liability: Both names on the lease; confirm sublet/early-termination clauses. Get renters insurance and list both of you.
- Money mechanics: Decide whether 50/50 still feels fair if incomes differ; otherwise do proportional rent. Open a shared “house” account or use Splitwise; set autopay for rent/utilities.
- Purchases and ownership: Track big buys in a shared sheet with who paid; keep receipts. Agree on buyout rules if one of you keeps an item.
- Chores and standards: Assign by preference/strength, set a weekly cleaning block, and schedule a monthly deep clean or a cleaner.
- Daily-life friction points: Quiet hours, thermostat range, guests/family stays, WFH schedules, alone time, and pet plans—write default rules.
- Communication cadence: A 30-minute weekly check-in (money, chores, plans, anything bugging you) to prevent build-ups.
- Future alignment: Be explicit about what moving in means (e.g., timeline for engagement/kids/relocation) so expectations match.

Quick decorating tips for a shared vibe:
- Build a joint mood board; choose a neutral base + 1–2 accent colors you both like.
- Buy the “big three” first: quality mattress, sofa, dining table. Live with the space 30 days before filling in.
- Unify finishes: keep wood tones and metals consistent room-to-room; repeat 2–3 textures (e.g., linen, leather, natural wood).
- Layer lighting: overhead + floor/task + ambient; use warm bulbs (2700–3000K) and dimmers.
- Use area rugs to define zones and cut noise; size them generously.
- Adopt a two-veto rule: either of you can nix an item, no questions asked.
- Storage early: entryway hooks/bench, shoe rack, cable management, a cleaning closet setup.
- Hang art at eye level (about 57–60"), mix both your tastes, and add a few plants to soften the space.

Bottom line: You’re approaching this like adults. With the exit plan and a few logistics finalized, this is a strong green light.

Score: 3/10 as currently planned.

Why I’m rating it low:
- You’re wiring a large deposit to a boyfriend of 4 months instead of paying a verified landlord/property manager. That’s a major financial and safety risk. “Identity theft messed up my credit” plus a high deposit and urgency are classic pressure flags. At minimum, your name should be on the lease and money should go directly to the property manager, not him.
- You’re quitting your job without another lined up, in a new city, becoming financially dependent on someone you barely know in real life. That shrinks your safety net and leverage.
- The pace is very fast: four months, long‑distance, ring talk, daily love-bomb-y contact, “apartment won’t last long.” Intensity isn’t the same as stability.
- You have $18k, but Portland job searches can take 2–4+ months, and moving costs add up. If the relationship or job hunt goes sideways, you could burn through savings quickly.
- Your family’s concerns and your sister’s “too smooth” comment might be data, not jealousy. People close to us often notice risk we minimize when we’re excited.

How to raise this to a 7–8/10:
- Do not wire him money. Call the property management company yourself, verify the unit and lease, and pay the deposit directly to them. Ensure you’re on the lease. If he resists this, that’s a huge red flag.
- Delay your notice at work if possible. Apply aggressively now, line up interviews, and try to secure a job (or remote arrangement) before moving.
- Consider a 2–4 week trial stay (Airbnb/sublet) while you interview. Keep your current place/job until you’ve verified the situation and daily compatibility.
- Keep finances separate. Do not co-sign loans. Keep a 6–9 month emergency fund in an account only you control, and a paid way home.
- Verify his story: ask for documentation of the identity theft and why his credit still impacts the deposit. Look up his business, clients, and references.
- Set clear expectations in writing for rent split, utilities, chores, guests, quiet hours, conflict resolution, and what happens if it doesn’t work.
- Build an exit plan: copies of documents, independent transportation, a friend who knows your plan and checks in, and a fallback housing option.

Portland job search tips:
- Start now: switch your LinkedIn location to Portland, update your headline, and turn on “open to work.” Message recruiters at Boly:Welch, 52 Limited (creative/tech), VanderHouwen (tech), Scion Staffing, and Robert Half. Check Mac’s List, WorkSource Oregon/iMatchSkills, PDX Pipeline, OregonLive Jobs, and Oregon state/city jobs.
- Network: PDXWIT (if you’re in/near tech), local Meetups, CreativeMornings PDX, industry Slack/Discord groups, and alumni networks. Ask for 15‑min virtual coffees with Portland folks in your field.
- Budget realistically: no sales tax in Oregon, but state income tax is significant; rents and car insurance may differ. Plan for 3–6 months runway.

Bottom line: the love and the move could be great, but the way you’re doing it exposes you to avoidable risks—especially sending him the deposit and quitting without income. Slow the logistics, verify everything, and protect your money and options. That shifts this from a 3/10 gamble to a solid 7–8/10 choice.

Portland neighborhood quick takes:

Why: The practical upsides are real (timing, cost, his family, the thoughtfulness). But moving in primarily to be his caregiver while he’s using non‑prescribed pills is a major red flag. It’s unsafe and illegal, and it sets up a partner-as-nurse dynamic that can quickly become codependent. Your “I think I overreacted” reads like you’re minimizing a serious issue. As a nurse, managing or dispensing his meds at home could also put your license and career at risk.

What I’d want in place before moving in (this would push it to a 7–8/10):
- One prescriber/pain-management plan, one pharmacy, and zero non‑prescribed pills. Ask for 60–90 days of adherence to that plan first.
- You are not his taper manager. He works with a pain specialist (and addiction‑informed clinician if needed). You support, you don’t dispense or hold meds.
- Clear written boundaries about caretaking vs. partner time, chores, and finances; keep finances separate and have an exit plan/trial period.
- Safety: secure medication storage if controlled meds are in the home; keep naloxone and know how to use it.
- A frank conversation (or a couple session) about what happens if pain spikes or boundaries are crossed—especially a zero‑tolerance line for any non‑prescribed substances.

If you move in anyway, make “no non‑prescribed meds” a non‑negotiable from day one and be prepared to follow through if it’s violated. You can be supportive without becoming his clinician—that’s the difference between a healthy next step and a risky one.

To make it a 10/10, button up these details before you move boxes:

- Power balance and “our home” feel: commit to shared decision‑making on common spaces; set aside a space that’s truly yours; plan a couple of joint projects (paint, furniture) early on.
- Money transparency: share high‑level numbers (debts, savings goals, credit, emergency fund), decide on separate vs. joint accounts for household expenses, and set a monthly budget check‑in.
